14#ifndef ISC_MEM_H
15#define ISC_MEM_H 1
16
17/*! \file isc/mem.h */
18
19#include <stdbool.h>
20#include <stdio.h>
21
22#include <isc/json.h>
23#include <isc/lang.h>
24#include <isc/mutex.h>
25#include <isc/platform.h>
26#include <isc/types.h>
27#include <isc/xml.h>
28
29ISC_LANG_BEGINDECLS
30
31#define ISC_MEM_LOWATER 0
32#define ISC_MEM_HIWATER 1
33typedef void (*isc_mem_water_t)(void *, int);
34
35typedef void * (*isc_memalloc_t)(void *, size_t);
36typedef void (*isc_memfree_t)(void *, void *);
37
38/*%
39 * Define ISC_MEM_TRACKLINES=1 to turn on detailed tracing of memory
40 * allocation and freeing by file and line number.
41 */
42#ifndef ISC_MEM_TRACKLINES
43#define ISC_MEM_TRACKLINES 1
44#endif
45
46/*%
47 * Define ISC_MEM_CHECKOVERRUN=1 to turn on checks for using memory outside
48 * the requested space. This will increase the size of each allocation.
49 *
50 * If we are performing a Coverity static analysis then ISC_MEM_CHECKOVERRUN
51 * can hide bugs that would otherwise discovered so force to zero.
52 */
53#ifdef __COVERITY__
54#undef ISC_MEM_CHECKOVERRUN
55#define ISC_MEM_CHECKOVERRUN 0
56#endif
57#ifndef ISC_MEM_CHECKOVERRUN
58#define ISC_MEM_CHECKOVERRUN 1
59#endif
60
61/*%
62 * Define ISC_MEMPOOL_NAMES=1 to make memory pools store a symbolic
63 * name so that the leaking pool can be more readily identified in
64 * case of a memory leak.
65 */
66#ifndef ISC_MEMPOOL_NAMES
67#define ISC_MEMPOOL_NAMES 1
68#endif
69
70LIBISC_EXTERNAL_DATA extern unsigned int isc_mem_debugging;
71LIBISC_EXTERNAL_DATA extern unsigned int isc_mem_defaultflags;
72
73/*@{*/
74#define ISC_MEM_DEBUGTRACE 0x00000001U
75#define ISC_MEM_DEBUGRECORD 0x00000002U
76#define ISC_MEM_DEBUGUSAGE 0x00000004U
77#define ISC_MEM_DEBUGSIZE 0x00000008U
78#define ISC_MEM_DEBUGCTX 0x00000010U
79#define ISC_MEM_DEBUGALL 0x0000001FU
80/*!<
81 * The variable isc_mem_debugging holds a set of flags for
82 * turning certain memory debugging options on or off at
83 * runtime. It is initialized to the value ISC_MEM_DEGBUGGING,
84 * which is 0 by default but may be overridden at compile time.
85 * The following flags can be specified:
86 *
87 * \li #ISC_MEM_DEBUGTRACE
88 * Log each allocation and free to isc_lctx.
89 *
90 * \li #ISC_MEM_DEBUGRECORD
91 * Remember each allocation, and match them up on free.
92 * Crash if a free doesn't match an allocation.
93 *
94 * \li #ISC_MEM_DEBUGUSAGE
95 * If a hi_water mark is set, print the maximum inuse memory
96 * every time it is raised once it exceeds the hi_water mark.
97 *
98 * \li #ISC_MEM_DEBUGSIZE
99 * Check the size argument being passed to isc_mem_put() matches
100 * that passed to isc_mem_get().
101 *
102 * \li #ISC_MEM_DEBUGCTX
103 * Check the mctx argument being passed to isc_mem_put() matches
104 * that passed to isc_mem_get().
105 */
106/*@}*/
107
108#if ISC_MEM_TRACKLINES
109#define _ISC_MEM_FILELINE , __FILE__, __LINE__
110#define _ISC_MEM_FLARG , const char *, unsigned int
111#else
112#define _ISC_MEM_FILELINE
113#define _ISC_MEM_FLARG
114#endif
115
116/*!
117 * Define ISC_MEM_USE_INTERNAL_MALLOC=1 to use the internal malloc()
118 * implementation in preference to the system one. The internal malloc()
119 * is very space-efficient, and quite fast on uniprocessor systems. It
120 * performs poorly on multiprocessor machines.
121 * JT: we can overcome the performance issue on multiprocessor machines
122 * by carefully separating memory contexts.
123 */
124
125#ifndef ISC_MEM_USE_INTERNAL_MALLOC
126#define ISC_MEM_USE_INTERNAL_MALLOC 1
127#endif
128
129/*
130 * Flags for isc_mem_createx() calls.
131 */
132#define ISC_MEMFLAG_NOLOCK 0x00000001 /* no lock is necessary */
133#define ISC_MEMFLAG_INTERNAL 0x00000002 /* use internal malloc */
134#define ISC_MEMFLAG_FILL 0x00000004 /* fill with pattern after alloc and frees */
135
136#if !ISC_MEM_USE_INTERNAL_MALLOC
137#define ISC_MEMFLAG_DEFAULT 0
138#else
139#define ISC_MEMFLAG_DEFAULT ISC_MEMFLAG_INTERNAL|ISC_MEMFLAG_FILL
140#endif
141
142/*%
143 * isc_mem_putanddetach() is a convenience function for use where you
144 * have a structure with an attached memory context.
145 *
146 * Given:
147 *
148 * \code
149 * struct {
150 * ...
151 * isc_mem_t *mctx;
152 * ...
153 * } *ptr;
154 *
155 * isc_mem_t *mctx;
156 *
157 * isc_mem_putanddetach(&ptr->mctx, ptr, sizeof(*ptr));
158 * \endcode
159 *
160 * is the equivalent of:
161 *
162 * \code
163 * mctx = NULL;
164 * isc_mem_attach(ptr->mctx, &mctx);
165 * isc_mem_detach(&ptr->mctx);
166 * isc_mem_put(mctx, ptr, sizeof(*ptr));
167 * isc_mem_detach(&mctx);
168 * \endcode
169 */
170
171/*% memory and memory pool methods */
172typedef struct isc_memmethods {
173 void *(*memget)(isc_mem_t *mctx, size_t size _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
174 void (*memput)(isc_mem_t *mctx, void *ptr, size_t size _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
175 void (*memputanddetach)(isc_mem_t **mctxp, void *ptr,
176 size_t size _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
177 void *(*memallocate)(isc_mem_t *mctx, size_t size _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
178 void *(*memreallocate)(isc_mem_t *mctx, void *ptr,
179 size_t size _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
180 char *(*memstrdup)(isc_mem_t *mctx, const char *s _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
181 void (*memfree)(isc_mem_t *mctx, void *ptr _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
182} isc_memmethods_t;
183
184/*%
185 * This structure is actually just the common prefix of a memory context
186 * implementation's version of an isc_mem_t.
187 * \brief
188 * Direct use of this structure by clients is forbidden. mctx implementations
189 * may change the structure. 'magic' must be ISCAPI_MCTX_MAGIC for any of the
190 * isc_mem_ routines to work. mctx implementations must maintain all mctx
191 * invariants.
192 */
193struct isc_mem {
194 unsigned int impmagic;
195 unsigned int magic;
196 isc_memmethods_t *methods;
197};
198
199#define ISCAPI_MCTX_MAGIC ISC_MAGIC('A','m','c','x')
200#define ISCAPI_MCTX_VALID(m) ((m) != NULL && \
201 (m)->magic == ISCAPI_MCTX_MAGIC)
202
203/*%
204 * This is the common prefix of a memory pool context. The same note as
205 * that for the mem structure applies.
206 */
207struct isc_mempool {
208 unsigned int impmagic;
209 unsigned int magic;
210};
211
212#define ISCAPI_MPOOL_MAGIC ISC_MAGIC('A','m','p','l')
213#define ISCAPI_MPOOL_VALID(mp) ((mp) != NULL && \
214 (mp)->magic == ISCAPI_MPOOL_MAGIC)
215
216/*%
217 * These functions are actually implemented in isc__mem_<function>
218 * (two underscores). The single-underscore macros are used to pass
219 * __FILE__ and __LINE__, and in the case of the put functions, to
220 * set the pointer being freed to NULL in the calling function.
221 *
222 * Many of these functions have a further isc___mem_<function>
223 * (three underscores) implementation, which is called indirectly
224 * via the isc_memmethods structure in the mctx so that dynamically
225 * loaded modules can use them even if named is statically linked.
226 */
227
228#define ISCMEMFUNC(sfx) isc__mem_ ## sfx
229#define ISCMEMPOOLFUNC(sfx) isc__mempool_ ## sfx
230
231#define isc_mem_get(c, s) ISCMEMFUNC(get)((c), (s) _ISC_MEM_FILELINE)
232#define isc_mem_allocate(c, s) ISCMEMFUNC(allocate)((c), (s) _ISC_MEM_FILELINE)
233#define isc_mem_reallocate(c, p, s) ISCMEMFUNC(reallocate)((c), (p), (s) _ISC_MEM_FILELINE)
234#define isc_mem_strdup(c, p) ISCMEMFUNC(strdup)((c), (p) _ISC_MEM_FILELINE)
235#define isc_mempool_get(c) ISCMEMPOOLFUNC(get)((c) _ISC_MEM_FILELINE)
236
237#define isc_mem_put(c, p, s) \
238 do { \
239 ISCMEMFUNC(put)((c), (p), (s) _ISC_MEM_FILELINE); \
240 (p) = NULL; \
241 } while (/*CONSTCOND*/0)
242#define isc_mem_putanddetach(c, p, s) \
243 do { \
244 ISCMEMFUNC(putanddetach)((c), (p), (s) _ISC_MEM_FILELINE); \
245 (p) = NULL; \
246 } while (/*CONSTCOND*/0)
247#define isc_mem_free(c, p) \
248 do { \
249 ISCMEMFUNC(free)((c), (p) _ISC_MEM_FILELINE); \
250 (p) = NULL; \
251 } while (/*CONSTCOND*/0)
252#define isc_mempool_put(c, p) \
253 do { \
254 ISCMEMPOOLFUNC(put)((c), (p) _ISC_MEM_FILELINE); \
255 (p) = NULL; \
256 } while (/*CONSTCOND*/0)
257
258/*@{*/
259isc_result_t
260isc_mem_create(size_t max_size, size_t target_size,
261 isc_mem_t **mctxp);
262
263isc_result_t
264isc_mem_createx(size_t max_size, size_t target_size,
265 isc_memalloc_t memalloc, isc_memfree_t memfree,
266 void *arg, isc_mem_t **mctxp, unsigned int flags);
267
268/*!<
269 * \brief Create a memory context.
270 *
271 * 'max_size' and 'target_size' are tuning parameters. When
272 * ISC_MEMFLAG_INTERNAL is set, allocations smaller than 'max_size'
273 * will be satisfied by getting blocks of size 'target_size' from the
274 * system allocator and breaking them up into pieces; larger allocations
275 * will use the system allocator directly. If 'max_size' and/or
276 * 'target_size' are zero, default values will be * used. When
277 * ISC_MEMFLAG_INTERNAL is not set, 'target_size' is ignored.
278 *
279 * 'max_size' is also used to size the statistics arrays and the array
280 * used to record active memory when ISC_MEM_DEBUGRECORD is set. Setting
281 * 'max_size' too low can have detrimental effects on performance.
282 *
283 * A memory context created using isc_mem_createx() will obtain
284 * memory from the system by calling 'memalloc' and 'memfree',
285 * passing them the argument 'arg'. A memory context created
286 * using isc_mem_create() will use the standard library malloc()
287 * and free().
288 *
289 * If ISC_MEMFLAG_NOLOCK is set in 'flags', the corresponding memory context
290 * will be accessed without locking. The user who creates the context must
291 * ensure there be no race. Since this can be a source of bug, it is generally
292 * inadvisable to use this flag unless the user is very sure about the race
293 * condition and the access to the object is highly performance sensitive.
294 *
295 * Requires:
296 * mctxp != NULL && *mctxp == NULL */
297/*@}*/
298
299/*@{*/
300void
301isc_mem_attach(isc_mem_t *, isc_mem_t **);
302void
303isc_mem_detach(isc_mem_t **);
304/*!<
305 * \brief Attach to / detach from a memory context.
306 *
307 * This is intended for applications that use multiple memory contexts
308 * in such a way that it is not obvious when the last allocations from
309 * a given context has been freed and destroying the context is safe.
310 *
311 * Most applications do not need to call these functions as they can
312 * simply create a single memory context at the beginning of main()
313 * and destroy it at the end of main(), thereby guaranteeing that it
314 * is not destroyed while there are outstanding allocations.
315 */
316/*@}*/
317
318void
319isc_mem_destroy(isc_mem_t **);
320/*%<
321 * Destroy a memory context.
322 */
323
324void
325isc_mem_stats(isc_mem_t *mctx, FILE *out);
326/*%<
327 * Print memory usage statistics for 'mctx' on the stream 'out'.
328 */
329
330void
331isc_mem_setdestroycheck(isc_mem_t *mctx,
332 bool on);
333/*%<
334 * If 'on' is true, 'mctx' will check for memory leaks when
335 * destroyed and abort the program if any are present.
336 */
337
338size_t
339isc_mem_inuse(isc_mem_t *mctx);
340/*%<
341 * Get an estimate of the amount of memory in use in 'mctx', in bytes.
342 * This includes quantization overhead, but does not include memory
343 * allocated from the system but not yet used.
344 */
345
346size_t
347isc_mem_maxinuse(isc_mem_t *mctx);
348/*%<
349 * Get an estimate of the largest amount of memory that has been in
350 * use in 'mctx' at any time.
351 */
352
353size_t
354isc_mem_total(isc_mem_t *mctx);
355/*%<
356 * Get the total amount of memory in 'mctx', in bytes, including memory
357 * not yet used.
358 */
359
360bool
361isc_mem_isovermem(isc_mem_t *mctx);
362/*%<
363 * Return true iff the memory context is in "over memory" state, i.e.,
364 * a hiwater mark has been set and the used amount of memory has exceeds
365 * the mark.
366 */
367
368void
369isc_mem_setwater(isc_mem_t *mctx, isc_mem_water_t water, void *water_arg,
370 size_t hiwater, size_t lowater);
371/*%<
372 * Set high and low water marks for this memory context.
373 *
374 * When the memory usage of 'mctx' exceeds 'hiwater',
375 * '(water)(water_arg, #ISC_MEM_HIWATER)' will be called. 'water' needs to
376 * call isc_mem_waterack() with #ISC_MEM_HIWATER to acknowledge the state
377 * change. 'water' may be called multiple times.
378 *
379 * When the usage drops below 'lowater', 'water' will again be called, this
380 * time with #ISC_MEM_LOWATER. 'water' need to calls isc_mem_waterack() with
381 * #ISC_MEM_LOWATER to acknowledge the change.
382 *
383 * static void
384 * water(void *arg, int mark) {
385 * struct foo *foo = arg;
386 *
387 * LOCK(&foo->marklock);
388 * if (foo->mark != mark) {
389 * foo->mark = mark;
390 * ....
391 * isc_mem_waterack(foo->mctx, mark);
392 * }
393 * UNLOCK(&foo->marklock);
394 * }
395 *
396 * If 'water' is NULL then 'water_arg', 'hi_water' and 'lo_water' are
397 * ignored and the state is reset.
398 *
399 * Requires:
400 *
401 * 'water' is not NULL.
402 * hi_water >= lo_water
403 */
404
405void
406isc_mem_waterack(isc_mem_t *ctx, int mark);
407/*%<
408 * Called to acknowledge changes in signaled by calls to 'water'.
409 */
410
411void
412isc_mem_checkdestroyed(FILE *file);
413/*%<
414 * Check that all memory contexts have been destroyed.
415 * Prints out those that have not been.
416 * Fatally fails if there are still active contexts.
417 */
418
419unsigned int
420isc_mem_references(isc_mem_t *ctx);
421/*%<
422 * Return the current reference count.
423 */
424
425void
426isc_mem_setname(isc_mem_t *ctx, const char *name, void *tag);
427/*%<
428 * Name 'ctx'.
429 *
430 * Notes:
431 *
432 *\li Only the first 15 characters of 'name' will be copied.
433 *
434 *\li 'tag' is for debugging purposes only.
435 *
436 * Requires:
437 *
438 *\li 'ctx' is a valid ctx.
439 */
440
441const char *
442isc_mem_getname(isc_mem_t *ctx);
443/*%<
444 * Get the name of 'ctx', as previously set using isc_mem_setname().
445 *
446 * Requires:
447 *\li 'ctx' is a valid ctx.
448 *
449 * Returns:
450 *\li A non-NULL pointer to a null-terminated string.
451 * If the ctx has not been named, the string is
452 * empty.
453 */
454
455void *
456isc_mem_gettag(isc_mem_t *ctx);
457/*%<
458 * Get the tag value for 'task', as previously set using isc_mem_setname().
459 *
460 * Requires:
461 *\li 'ctx' is a valid ctx.
462 *
463 * Notes:
464 *\li This function is for debugging purposes only.
465 *
466 * Requires:
467 *\li 'ctx' is a valid task.
468 */
469
470#ifdef HAVE_LIBXML2
471int
472isc_mem_renderxml(xmlTextWriterPtr writer);
473/*%<
474 * Render all contexts' statistics and status in XML for writer.
475 */
476#endif /* HAVE_LIBXML2 */
477
478#ifdef HAVE_JSON
479isc_result_t
480isc_mem_renderjson(json_object *memobj);
481/*%<
482 * Render all contexts' statistics and status in JSON.
483 */
484#endif /* HAVE_JSON */
485
486
487/*
488 * Memory pools
489 */
490
491isc_result_t
492isc_mempool_create(isc_mem_t *mctx, size_t size, isc_mempool_t **mpctxp);
493/*%<
494 * Create a memory pool.
495 *
496 * Requires:
497 *\li mctx is a valid memory context.
498 *\li size > 0
499 *\li mpctxp != NULL and *mpctxp == NULL
500 *
501 * Defaults:
502 *\li maxalloc = UINT_MAX
503 *\li freemax = 1
504 *\li fillcount = 1
505 *
506 * Returns:
507 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY -- not enough memory to create pool
508 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well.
509 */
510
511void
512isc_mempool_destroy(isc_mempool_t **mpctxp);
513/*%<
514 * Destroy a memory pool.
515 *
516 * Requires:
517 *\li mpctxp != NULL && *mpctxp is a valid pool.
518 *\li The pool has no un"put" allocations outstanding
519 */
520
521void
522isc_mempool_setname(isc_mempool_t *mpctx, const char *name);
523/*%<
524 * Associate a name with a memory pool. At most 15 characters may be used.
525 *
526 * Requires:
527 *\li mpctx is a valid pool.
528 *\li name != NULL;
529 */
530
531void
532isc_mempool_associatelock(isc_mempool_t *mpctx, isc_mutex_t *lock);
533/*%<
534 * Associate a lock with this memory pool.
535 *
536 * This lock is used when getting or putting items using this memory pool,
537 * and it is also used to set or get internal state via the isc_mempool_get*()
538 * and isc_mempool_set*() set of functions.
539 *
540 * Multiple pools can each share a single lock. For instance, if "manager"
541 * type object contained pools for various sizes of events, and each of
542 * these pools used a common lock. Note that this lock must NEVER be used
543 * by other than mempool routines once it is given to a pool, since that can
544 * easily cause double locking.
545 *
546 * Requires:
547 *
548 *\li mpctpx is a valid pool.
549 *
550 *\li lock != NULL.
551 *
552 *\li No previous lock is assigned to this pool.
553 *
554 *\li The lock is initialized before calling this function via the normal
555 * means of doing that.
556 */
557
558/*
559 * The following functions get/set various parameters. Note that due to
560 * the unlocked nature of pools these are potentially random values unless
561 * the imposed externally provided locking protocols are followed.
562 *
563 * Also note that the quota limits will not always take immediate effect.
564 * For instance, setting "maxalloc" to a number smaller than the currently
565 * allocated count is permitted. New allocations will be refused until
566 * the count drops below this threshold.
567 *
568 * All functions require (in addition to other requirements):
569 * mpctx is a valid memory pool
570 */
571
572unsigned int
573isc_mempool_getfreemax(isc_mempool_t *mpctx);
574/*%<
575 * Returns the maximum allowed size of the free list.
576 */
577
578void
579isc_mempool_setfreemax(isc_mempool_t *mpctx, unsigned int limit);
580/*%<
581 * Sets the maximum allowed size of the free list.
582 */
583
584unsigned int
585isc_mempool_getfreecount(isc_mempool_t *mpctx);
586/*%<
587 * Returns current size of the free list.
588 */
589
590unsigned int
591isc_mempool_getmaxalloc(isc_mempool_t *mpctx);
592/*!<
593 * Returns the maximum allowed number of allocations.
594 */
595
596void
597isc_mempool_setmaxalloc(isc_mempool_t *mpctx, unsigned int limit);
598/*%<
599 * Sets the maximum allowed number of allocations.
600 *
601 * Additional requirements:
602 *\li limit > 0
603 */
604
605unsigned int
606isc_mempool_getallocated(isc_mempool_t *mpctx);
607/*%<
608 * Returns the number of items allocated from this pool.
609 */
610
611unsigned int
612isc_mempool_getfillcount(isc_mempool_t *mpctx);
613/*%<
614 * Returns the number of items allocated as a block from the parent memory
615 * context when the free list is empty.
616 */
617
618void
619isc_mempool_setfillcount(isc_mempool_t *mpctx, unsigned int limit);
620/*%<
621 * Sets the fillcount.
622 *
623 * Additional requirements:
624 *\li limit > 0
625 */
626
627
628/*
629 * Pseudo-private functions for use via macros. Do not call directly.
630 */
631void *
632ISCMEMFUNC(get)(isc_mem_t *, size_t _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
633void
634ISCMEMFUNC(putanddetach)(isc_mem_t **, void *, size_t _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
635void
636ISCMEMFUNC(put)(isc_mem_t *, void *, size_t _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
637void *
638ISCMEMFUNC(allocate)(isc_mem_t *, size_t _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
639void *
640ISCMEMFUNC(reallocate)(isc_mem_t *, void *, size_t _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
641void
642ISCMEMFUNC(free)(isc_mem_t *, void * _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
643char *
644ISCMEMFUNC(strdup)(isc_mem_t *, const char *_ISC_MEM_FLARG);
645void *
646ISCMEMPOOLFUNC(get)(isc_mempool_t * _ISC_MEM_FLARG);
647void
648ISCMEMPOOLFUNC(put)(isc_mempool_t *, void * _ISC_MEM_FLARG);

652#endif /* ISC_MEM_H */
